abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental management plan
            for Georgia's Protected Areas Development Project,
            improves the conservation and sustainable use of Georgian
            biodiversity. Negative environmental impacts include the
            following: The small-scale construction of infrastructure
            will have minor, short-term direct impacts on vegetation and
            local species-mainly due to soil excavation, dust, and
            noise. Increased recreational use of project sites may
            produce a direct impact because of under-management of
            tourist sites and facilities, possible overuse of campsites
            or trails, increased waste, harvesting of live wood for
            campfires, purposeful disturbance of wildlife, accidental
            fires, disturbance of flora and fauna, trespassing into
            fragile areas, and non-maintenance of trails lading to slope
            erosion. Mitigation measures include: incorporating
            environmental considerations into engineering design to
            ensure that waste is managed: waste bins, and technology for
            toilet facilities like leaching fields, organic composting,
            and septic tanks. To reduce pressure on overgrazed
            pasturelands, park administration will provide shepherds
            with basic extension services and provide basic veterinary
            assistance. Reducing the level of grazing through land
            zoning will reduce disturbances to wildlife, in particular
            the mountain goat. Shepherds will be allocated new grazing
            leases to replace existing leases within park boundaries.
